data.question: Hardworking students must not have a finger in every pie at school.

option.a: Hardworking students must not have a role to play in most activities in the school
option.b: Only hardworking students must participate in all activities in the school
option.c: Hardworking students do not participate in all activities in the school
option.d: Hardworking students must ask others to participate in school activities

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: Someone who has a finger in every pie is involved in a lot of different activities or knows about a lot of different things.

data.question: The vice chancellor is riding the crest of the last quarter of his administration.

option.a: The vice chancellor enjoys the acknowledgment of the success of his administration
option.b: the vice chancellor does not enjoy the people's criticism of his administration
option.c: the vice chancellor hopes to overcome soon the poor comments on the adinistration
option.d: the vice chancellor does not talk of his success in office

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: This means to be experiencing a particularly joyous or successful period, situation, or event. ei, the vice chancellor is enjoying the successes of his administration.

data.question: She was absolved by the court from the charge.

option.a: she was convicted for the charge
option.b: she was blamed and charged to court
option.c: her case was resolved by the court
option.d: she was declared free from the charge

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: To declare (someone) free from guilt, obligation, or punishment.

data.question: The landlord is fond of throwing his weight about

option.c: the landlord gives orders to people
option.d: the landlord is respected by his tenants

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: Throw (one's) weight around. to use your position or influence unfairly to get what you want

data.question: The company ought to have issued warrants for one billion shares

option.a: the company has issued one billion share
option.b: the management expected the company to issue more than one billion shares
option.c: members of the company bought less than one billion shares
option.d: the company did not issue one billion shares

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution:
ought to have'' is used when you realize that someone did not do the right thing in the past.

something that was meant to be done, but wasn't done.

data.question: He needed not to have played in the position of quarterback in volley ball.

option.a: He participated in the game in his unusual position
option.b: Nobody expected him to have participated in the game
option.c: He wanted to play in a position other than the one he was offered
option.d: Someone did not want him to play in the position that he played

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: This means he did not have to have played in the position he played in. He played in a wrong position

data.question: I wouldn't have responded to his rude talk, if l were you

option.a: the advice was taken by the respondent so he did not respond to the talk
option.b: the adviser put himself in the respondent's position, so he did not respond to the talk
option.c: the respondent replied to the speaker's talk, althought he ought not have done so
option.d: what was advisable was that the respondent gave it back to the speaker

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution:
Two people are involved in this conversation. The adviser and the respondent. The adviser puts himself in the respondent position, and advised that  it was needless in responding to the rude conversation the respondent had with someone .

This means that, the respondent reacted to the rude talk, but the adviser wished he had ignored the talk instead.

data.question: He could not speak out because he had a feet of clay.
data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: If you say that a person who is respected or admired has feet of clay, you mean that they have serious faults which you or other people did not know about before. A fundamental flaw or weakness in a person otherwise revered.

data.question: The player wasted a golden opportunity during the penalty shoot-out

option.a: The player first hit the bar
option.b: The player did not score the shot
option.c: The player scored the shot that made them win the gold cup
option.d: instead of a silver cup, they received the golden one

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: The player missed a good chance to do or succeed at sccoring,

data.question: As far as Abu is concerned , Mero should be given fifty naira at the most

option.a: All Abu is concerned with is that Mero should be given nothing more than fifty naira
option.b: All Abu is saying is that Mero probably desrves more than fifty naira and not less
option.c: In Abu's estimation, Mero merits not more than fifty naira
option.d: In Abu's opinion, Mero deserves fifty naira or probably more

data.section: LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of question 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence
data.solution: at the most means, not more than.

data.question: As an <u>idiot</u>, the boy is weak in class
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Idiot; a person of low intelligence

data.question: We were <u>shocked</u> by the news that he had lost the money.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: shocked; cause (someone) to feel surprised and upset

data.question: The principal was advised to be <u>flexible</u> on critical issues.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
flexible; able to be easily modified to respond to altered circumstances.

Rigid; unable to bend or be forced out of shape; not flexible.

data.question: Bola always looks <u>sober</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: sober;serious, sensible, and solemn

data.question: Dupe was promoted for her <u>efficiency</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Efficient; (of a person) working in a well-organized and competent way.

data.question: The management wants to consider her <u>reticent</u> behaviour in due course.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Reticent; not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily. Reserved, withdrawn.

Loquacious; tending to talk a great deal; talkative.

data.question: Election processes often become <u>volatile</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: volatile; liable to change rapidly and unpredictably, especially for the worse. Tensed, uneasy

data.question: Oche entered the principal's office in a rather <u>abrasive</u> manner.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Abrasive; showing little concern for the feelings of others; harsh.

data.question: Otokpa is a member of the <u>ad hoc</u>committee on stock acquisition.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Ad hoc; when necessary or needed. something that has been formed or used for a special and immediate purpose, without previous planning. 

Formal; done in accordance with convention or etiquette; suitable for or constituting an official or important occasion

data.question: His gift to the poor was always <u>infinitesimal</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Infinitesimal; extremely small.

data.question: The economist concluded that several factors have been <u>adduced</u> to explain the fall in the birth rate.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Adduced; cite as evidence. To offer as example, reason, or proof in discussion or analysis.

Refuted; prove (a statement or theory) to be wrong or false; disprove.

data.question: The presidential system is an <u>antidote</u> to some political ailments.
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Antidote; something that counteracts an unpleasant feeling or situation. 

Obstacle; a thing that blocks one's way or prevents or hinders progress.

data.question: Ola thought that her father was very <u>callous</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Callous; showing or having an insensitive and cruel disregard for others.

compassionate; feeling or showing sympathy and concern for others.

data.question: He was very much respected, though he had no <u>temporal</u> power
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Temporal; in this context is relating to worldly as opposed to spiritual affairs; secular

data.question: The way the workshop was organized was rather <u>hit-and-miss</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 36 to 50 choose the option opposite in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Hit-and-miss; done or occurring at random.

Systematic; done or acting according to a fixed plan or system; methodical.

data.question: Some men will continue to cause offences until they are given <u>a taste of their own medicine</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: You use the expression 'A Taste of Your Own Medicine' to indicate that someone is. receiving the same unpleasant experience they've been dishing out to others

data.question: Okibe was rusticated for his <u>derogatory</u> remark about the principal
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Derogatory; showing a critical or disrespectful attitude.

Unsavoury; unappealing or disagreeable

data.question: Justice is difficult to enforce because people are unwilling to accept any loss <u>sovereignty</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
sovereignty; In this context it means people are unwilling to loss their independence. A self-governing state.

Autonomy; the right or condition of self-government.

data.question: There are still <u>virtuous</u> women in our society today
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: virtuous; having or showing high moral standards.

data.question: That type of response is <u>typical</u> of a lazy teacher
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Typical; representative as a symbol. symbolic.

characteristic; typical of a particular person, place, or thing.

data.question: Akin is an <u>inveterate</u> gambler
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Inveterate; of one having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change.

Incorrigible; (of a person or their behaviour) not able to be changed or reformed.

data.question: He was too <u>petrified</u> to give the closing remarks at the conference.
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: petrified ; so frightened that one is unable to move; terrified.

data.question: During a particular time of the day, the road <u>shimmers</u> in the heat
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
shimmers; shine with a soft, slightly wavering light.

 

Shines; (of the sun or another source of light) give out a bright light.

data.question: Every human being is <u>vulnerable</u> to communicable diseases.
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Someone who is vulnerable is weak and without protection, with the result that they are easily hurt physically or emotionally.

Liable; likely to experience (something undesirable).

data.question: Mariam looks rather <u>furtive</u> to Shehu
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Furtive; If a person's manner is furtive, he or she is acting suspiciously/ secretive/ sly.

Sly; having or showing a cunning and deceitful nature.

data.question: The student's union leader delivered his speech <u>extempore</u>
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Extempore; spoken or done without preparation.

off the cuff; without preparation.

data.question: His story gave us an <u>inkling</u> of what he passed through during the strike
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Inkling; means a slight knowledge or suspicion; a hint.

data.question: These policies have been <u>espoused</u> by the ruling party.
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution: Espoused;  to adopt or support (a cause, belief, or way of life).

data.question: We must not <u>foreclose</u> reconciliation as the purpose of his trip
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
Foreclose; rule out or prevent (a course of action).

Exclude; remove from consideration.

data.question: Her findings <u>exploded</u> widely held beliefs about learning.
data.section: In each of the questions 51 to 65 choose the option nearest in meaning to the underlined word or phrase.
data.solution:
In this context ''exploded '' means to show (a belief or theory) to be false or unfounded.

Debunked; expose the falseness or hollowness of (an idea or belief).

data.question: He was both a writer and a politician, but he was better...... a singer
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
As; is used in comparisons to refer to the extent or degree of something.

He was both a writer and a politician, but he was better as a singer

data.question: Vacancies in the company will be notified by...........
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
Advertisement; a notice or announcement in a public medium promoting a product, service, or event or publicizing a job vacancy.

Vacancies in the company will be notified by advertisement

data.question: He started his career as an..........teacher
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
Auxiliary; providing supplementary or additional help and support.

He started his career as an auxiliary teacher

data.question: The driver was short of petrol, so he..........down the hills with the engine switched off
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
glide means To move in a smooth, effortless manner: a submarine gliding through the water. See Synonyms at slide. 2. To move silently and furtively: The thief glided across the room.

coasted: To proceed with little effort. Because the route was mostly downhill, the car just coasted along. I'm worried that you're just coasting along through your senior year without taking your future seriously.

wheeled (of a vehicle or other object) having wheels to enable it to move over the ground.

taxied (of an aircraft) move slowly along the ground before take-off or after landing.

data.question: His many years of success in legal practice,…... didn’t come without challenges.
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)

data.question: One should be careful how......behaves in public, shouldn't.......
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution: One should be careful how one behaves in public, shouldn't one

data.question: ...........a good leader must have two characteristics
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
First and foremost; most importantly

first and foremost a good leader must have two characteristics

data.question: We visited his house...........three times
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
About is used to indicate movement within a particular area.

We visited his house about three times

data.question: We visited his house…...three times.
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)

data.question: She was............the verge of tears
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
Close to, on the brink of (something)

She was on the verge of tears

data.question: Everyone makes mistakes occasionally, nobody is.........
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
Infallible; incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.

Everyone makes mistakes occasionally, nobody is infallible

data.question: The woman would not part with her..........pot
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution: The woman would not part with her discarded black earthen pot

data.question: We stood up when the principal came in..........?
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
We often use question tags when we expect the listener to agree with our statement. In this case, when the statement is negative, we use a positive question tag. Hence it would read;

We stood up when the principal came in  didn't we

data.question: This professor of...........medicine has......... the mystery of bird flu.
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
veterinary; relating to the diseases, injuries, and treatment of farm and domestic animals.

unraveled; investigate and solve or explain something.

This professor of  veterinary medicine has unraveled the mystery of bird flu.

data.question: Her mother brought her some.......
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution: Her mother brought her some clothes

data.question: Many workers were............ as a result of the textile closure
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
If workers are laid off, they are told by their employers to leave their job, usually because there is no more work for them to do.

Many workers were laid off as a result of the textile closure

data.question: The driver died in the .......... road accident
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
Fatal; causing death.

The driver died in the fatal  road accident

data.question: _______your parents frown _______our friendship, we shouldn't see each other anymore
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)

data.question: ...........she didn't trust him, she married him.
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution:
Though; despite the fact that; although.

Though she didn't trust him, she married him.

data.question: I wanted to know his political beliefs, so l asked him what........
data.section: In each of the question 66 to 85 choose the option that best completes the gap(s)
data.solution: I wanted to know his political beliefs, so l asked him what they were

data.question: Demarcation
data.section: In each of questions, 92 to 94, choose the appropriate stress pattern from the options. The syllables are underlined in capital letters.
data.solution:
Words ending with ''tion'' are stressed on the syllable before the ''tion''. Hence demarcation would be stressed as;
de-mar-CA-tion

data.question: Imperialism
data.section: In each of questions, 92 to 94, choose the appropriate stress pattern from the options. The syllables are underlined in capital letters.
In each of the questions, 95 to 97 choose the option that has the stress on the first syllable
data.solution: One common pronunciation convention many guides provide is that nouns and adjectives with two or more syllables will have stress placed on the first syllable, while verbs and prepositions tend to have their stress on the second syllable

data.section: In each of the questions, 95 to 97 choose the option that has the stress on the first syllable
data.solution: In two syllable nouns and adjectives, the first syllable takes on the stress.

data.section: In each of the questions, 95 to 97 choose the option that has the stress on the first syllable
data.solution:
One common pronunciation convention many guides provide is that nouns and adjectives with two or more syllables will have stress placed on the first syllable, while verbs and prepositions tend to have their stress on the second syllable. Hence we have;

EX-port

data.question: The traditional chief NARRATED the story to the children

option.a: the children heard the story from the traditional chief
option.b: who narrated the story to the children?
option.c: the children could not listen to the story by the traditional chief
option.d: did the chief hide the story from the children?

data.section: In each of the questions 98 to 100 the word in capital letters has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence relates.
data.solution: In responding to questions on emphatic stress in examinations, interrogative sentences will be provided as options. The interrogative sentence that contradicts the emphasized word is the correct option. The word ''hide'' in option D contradicts the emphasized word ''narrate''

data.question: The ACCOUNTANT paid the workers' July salary in September.

option.b: did the cashier pay the workers' salary in September?
option.c: workers received their july salary in September
option.d: the September salary was paid in July?

data.section: In each of the questions 98 to 100 the word in capital letters has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence relates.
data.solution: In responding to questions on emphatic stress in examinations, interrogative sentences will be provided as options. The interrogative sentence that contradicts the emphasized word is the correct option.'''cashier'' contradicts the word ''accountant'

data.question: The cat DEVOURED the rat

option.a: did the rat devour the cat?
option.c: did the cat eat the rat?
option.d: Is this the rat that the cat devoured?

data.section: In each of the questions 98 to 100 the word in capital letters has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence relates.
data.solution: In responding to questions on emphatic stress, Interrogative sentence that contradicts the emphasized word is the correct option. This means that, the statement that does not have the emphasized word in it is the correct answer. Option C is the correct answer here because the word ''eat contradicts ''devour''
